awd_titl_txt: Biouptake of Mercury: Speciation and Processes at the Cell Surface
awd_abstract_narration:
The Environmental Chemical Sciences Program in the Chemistry Division at the National Science Foundation supports the research of Professor Jean-Francois Gaillard at Northwestern University who seeks to establish the processes that control the bioavailability of Mercury (Hg) in aquatic systems and particularly to better delineate the role played by complexation reactions with human made ligands.  Mercury biouptake by microbial species is a key step in the formation of methyl-mercury, one of the most potent neurotoxins known. Professor Gaillard will examine how bacterial surface processes regulate this process when the chemical speciation of Hg in solution is controlled by the presence of either anthropogenic or biogenic ligands. The interactions of Hg with cell binding sites will be investigated using spectroscopic and microscopic methods, whereas Hg biouptake will be assessed using a whole cell biosensor. Hg complexation reactions in solution will also be investigated using voltammetric methods. The goal of this research is to provide a molecular perspective on mercury biouptake as well as challenge conventional views on ligands controlled metal biouptake.
 
The exacerbation of the release of mercury to the global environment as a result of human activities such as coal burning has raised a general concern about this pollutant that is distributed worldwide. The proposed work has many essential connections to engineering applications and the protection of human and ecological health. It evaluates in both fundamental and practical ways the fate of Hg in response to anthropogenic releases and redefines Hg entry pathways into microbial foodwebs. This research program will train a Ph.D. and undergraduate students in environmental bioinorganic chemistry and develop collaborations with the industry that is working to control Hg concentrations in the environment.

por.por_cntn:
Anthropogenic activities have greatly enhanced the presence of mercury in aquatic systems, primarily nowadays through the burning of coal. Mercury is known as a toxic metal since it has no recognized biological function. As mercury can persist as a gas it can be transported over long distances through the atmosphere, hence it is considered as a global pollutant. Mercury usually reach aquatic environment as ionic mercury (Hg2+). However, humans are primarily exposed to mercury through the consumption of fish contaminated with another chemical form of mercury: mono-methylmercury (CH3Hg+). This compound turns out to be a potent neurotoxin that is formed naturally in waters that are depleted in dissolved di-oxygen (O2(aq)). This chemical transformation occurs in specific bacterial species after the transfer of mercury ions through the outer membranes of these microorganisms. In addition, we know that the chemical speciation of metals, i.e., their chemical form, regulates their bioavailability - that is the propensity of metals to be internalized by biological cells. In parallel to releasing metals in the environment, humans are also discharging various anthropogenic ligands, i.e., chemical species that have excellent binding capacities for metallic ions.

Intellectual Merit: The overall objective of this research was to advance our understanding of the processes controlling the uptake of mercury by microbial species, since it is a necessary step for the transformation of Hg2+ into CH3Hg+. We showed that widely used anthropogenic ligands – such as EDTA – promote the bio-uptake of mercury although the metal is predominantly bound in solution to the organic molecule. Using spectroscopic methods based on x-rays produced at synchrotron light research facilities we showed that the structure of the mercury-EDTA complex explained why the metal was undergoing ligand transfer reactions at the level of the cell membrane, prior to its biological uptake. In addition, we showed that the large increase in the biological uptake of mercury ions in presence of cysteine is related to the degradation of this ligand by the cells form sulfides that are also good ligand species for Hg2+. Our spectroscopic studies also showed that mercury sulfide precipitates formed during these biological uptake experiments when cysteine was present. From these experiments, we can conclude that, in the case of mercury, the current environmental paradigms of reduced metal bioavailability in presence ligands and/or sulfide need to be revised to account for the processes occurring at the level of biological membranes.

Broader Impact: The new insights gained from this research should have broad regulatory impacts with respect to the use of anthropogenic ligands in our daily lives. Indeed, they increase the mobility of metal contaminants in the aquatic environment and they appear to even promote biological uptake. This research also indicates that even. This research supported the PhD thesis of one female graduate student who is currently a postdoctoral researcher and the honor thesis of one undergraduate student in environmental engineering who is pursuing graduate studies towards a PhD. In addition, it provided partial support to an additional female PhD student, 2 undergraduate research assistant, and initiated to 2 high school students to research that were all mentored in part by the PhD student in charge of the project.
